text: So since it's a quantitative strategy, we need to always understand the conditions. Under what conditions trend following will work. And the condition is simple, as I said, simple or say advanced trend following, you always, we are trying to leverage continuous trends. So since it goes down, we leverage it. We are just not sticking to the positions. Even if we were to use binary signals, imagine that if things start to go down, more and more assets, say, treasures start going up, dollar up, commodities down. So even we use some kind of crossover, binary crossovers, we start accumulating the short exposure. And in this sense, what conditions do we need to perform? We need trends to continue. In other words, we need positive autocorrelation. If things go down, down today, it means probabilistically, they are more likely to go down tomorrow or on the way up. It is not enough for things to go up. Like in my recent presentation, I offered a simple market dynamic. One is dynamics where you say you toss a faulty coin, where probability of heads is, say, two thirds. And for each head, you get one dollar. So you are biased to go up. If you are a long-only investor and you say, you play this game, you're expected to go up your P&L. Trend followers also in this environment, of course, if trend followers are the ones who look at the most recent outcome. If, say, today was a tail, I bet on the tail on the next round. In the sense that we are trying to follow the most recent. And of course, if coin is biased, we also we are capturing it a little bit, not strongly, not as good as long-only investor. What matters for us is if the coin is biased in a way that if it shows head to now, on the next round, it conditionally will say two thirds probability of the head again. If it shows tail now, then conditionally, two thirds will be tail tomorrow. a trend follower that bets on the tail, so conditionally, still realizing effect can be negative for us, but in this way, for long-only investor, in this game, you get zero. So, to paraphrase, the trend following conditions, Conditions for trend following to perform is when market are autocorrelated in positive way, that trends are continuous. It is not enough just to see it to go up. It should be conditionally that they go up. And what happens during last decade, since go up, but for a different reason. It's just a drift. It's a drift that is not say conditionally not predictable. And moreover, we have gaps. So information disseminates very fast that we have gaps over very short periods of times. That no trend system is able to capture. And we have recovery. In a normal environment where trend following will benefit if these gaps continue to go down. Now we have the opposite. Every dip is bought. And when dip is bought, it means there is a mean reversion. And mean reversion is an environment where trend following, mathematically we can show. Of course, the answer is not such as it's satisfactory for a quant, for a person, maybe for a QR or for a person who understands the game, is not satisfactory for investors. So now what causes? Then we need to look into what causes this mean reversion. Of course, people will say, well, it's not a good idea. People refer to central bank policy, which is somewhat true that I think there's some way complacency that any dip needs to be bought. Then on the other hand, say in commodities market, I think also there's more many arbitrageurs now. A lot of commodity producers have their own trading desks that are trying to eliminate any kind of trade opportunity or any type of mismatch between different contracts. Traditionally, maybe trend following was much more diversified towards having some alphas in many markets. Across many markets, alphas that were, say, uncorrelated, it's either part of positive autocorrelation or part of carrying. And nowadays they don't exist. So to answer what's next, and I think the industry, as you rightly mentioned, I think most of the guys, they just try to increase the window. So less trade, less frequently. And trading less. And then question comes, how am I able to adapt to a fast changing environment? If things start changing again. Am I able to go transition to fast trend forward? So that's a question that investors have.
